title: and ZZTJ (176.5482) trace the east-west split to the war between Shabolue and Abo in 583. However, at that time, a separate western branch had been in existence under Datou. Supporting Abo against Shabolue, this western branch evolved into an independent Western Tujue empire. As for Abo and his line of successors, I follow Wu Yugui (1998, 18–32, 38–48) in treating them as a branch of Eastern Tujue. On different views concerning the split, see Liu Jianming

306. Although treated as a Western Tujue qaghan in the sources, Nili was an Eastern qaghan of the Abo (Apa) branch

note: Nishijima Sadao has advanced the thesis of the Sinitic cultural sphere for this period, composed of such elements as the Chinese written script, Confucianism, Buddhism based on sutras in Chinese translation, and legal codes and statutes. title: This scheme, allegedly that of the semilegendary sovereign Yu , is somewhat different from the nine fu system of the Zhou. But the basic concept is the same
